  physical_appearance: This is a copper inkwell made and painted to resemble a butterfly. The inkwell has detachable components. It has wings decorated with multi-colored enamel paint. The body of the butterfly is grey. The sizes of the inkwell is decorated with scrolling floral motifs.

  subject_terms_1: flower (motif) exports

  subject_terms_2: Inkwells Motifs Exports

  subject_terms_3: Chinese decorative arts

  sgcool_label_text: This copper inkwell is made and painted in vibrant colours to resemble a butterfly. The insect is an auspicious motif in Chinese culture and is often represented in paintings
 textiles and other mediums. In addition to signifying joy
 butterflies in pairs were also seen as symbols of marital bliss. The art of painting in enamels on copper was introduced from Europe into China during the late Kangxi period (1622-1722)
 probably by Jesuit missionaries
 and came into vogue in the 18th century. The bustling city of Guangzhou
 where this inkwell was likely made
 was an important production centre of enamelled metalwares for both the domestic and export markets during the Qing dynasty (1644–1911).

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a copper inkwell made and painted to resemble a butterfly. The inkwell has detachable components. It has wings decorated with multi-colored enamel paint. The body of the butterfly is grey. The sizes of the inkwell is decorated with scrolling floral motifs.
metadata.sgcool_label_text: This copper inkwell is made and painted in vibrant colours to resemble a butterfly. The insect is an auspicious motif in Chinese culture and is often represented in paintings, textiles and other mediums. In addition to signifying joy, butterflies in pairs were also seen as symbols of marital bliss. The art of painting in enamels on copper was introduced from Europe into China during the late Kangxi period (1622-1722), probably by Jesuit missionaries, and came into vogue in the 18th century. The bustling city of Guangzhou, where this inkwell was likely made, was an important production centre of enamelled metalwares for both the domestic and export markets during the Qing dynasty (1644–1911).
